segments.text: Where you were born?
Oh, I was born in a little town of Remsen, Iowa, about 20 miles out of Sioux City, Iowa,
in what was known as the Corn Belt of Iowa.
In what year?
So in the Depression, you'd be how old?
Well, as far as the Depression, the roof sort of fell.
The roof fell in about in 1929, I was 27 years old at that time.
And where were you then?
I was at Halbright.
Saskatchewan.
In the, you can say, Weyburn-Estevan area, and we had a farm.
I was brought up on a farm at Halbright.
Your whole family was there then?
Oh, yeah, we were a big family when we came up from Iowa.
We were, what, father and mother and 12 children, and one was born after we came.
Why did they move from Iowa?
Pardon?
Why did they move up?
That's a good question.
I've asked that many times during the dry years when the country blew out and everything
was against you.
Why did Dad ever leave Iowa?
But he homesteaded there, didn't he?
No, he didn't.
We bought land, and he paid a big price for it.
Prairie, you might say, and broke it up with horses, and did everything the hard way.
But he had a family.
He had a lot of manpower, this growing family.
The oldest one was 20 years old when we moved up here.
The oldest boy.
You were in the middle.
We were nine boys.
No, I was the seventh son.
And then there were girls after you.
There were three girls before me and one right after me, yes.
So you were near the end then.
So we were a big family.
So a lot of those boys stayed on the farm?
Oh, yes.
In those days.
You stayed home and worked for your keep until you were 21 years old.
And then you flew the coop, not like they do nowadays.
They want to go at 16 or 17.
We stayed home and you worked without wages until you were 21 years old.
And that was the standard.
Okay, so now you were 28 or 29 in the beginning of the Depression.
When the Depression started, yes.
And you had left home?
I left home when I was 24 years old.
What were you doing?
My father died when I was 21 years old.
And I was the oldest one home and I took over the management of the farm.
So what were you doing then when the Depression started?
Where were you?
I was back in the area and working.
I went into the power business or working at power in 1927.
And I started in Iowa, as queer as it may seem.
I started in Iowa.
I went to Nebraska.
I went to South Dakota.
I went to North Dakota.
And finally I wound up at Esalen in 1929.
And you were working for yourself?
With the power.
For yourself?
No, no.
I wasn't a contractor.
I was working for a power company.
Oh, a power company.
Yeah.
And started without any education or anything.
Just started from the bottom.
This is a private power company?
Yes.
At that time, we had private power companies in Saskatchewan.
The Power Commission didn't start until 1927.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
I see.
And then, in 1978, it was formed.
So what did you do?
What did I do?
A small power company.
Not really small either.
They had about 70 employees throughout the province.
And I, when I started in power, I started digging holes right from the bottom on the
end of the shovel, so to speak.
So in 1930, what were you doing?
I was a lineman by that time.
I graduated up and I was a, what they called a Hoff Lineman.
I could work anything.
And what, how much money did you make?
A little bit, yeah.
It was...
did you make in 1930 when i started then i was making 82 cents an hour and paying my own keep
was that good wages that was good yes extremely good now did your wages stay the same all the way
through the depression well no i have to stop and think now in 29 i i it was just by chance
that i got on with this power company in the meantime i had gone back on the farm
my brother and i started farming and then mother wanted to come back on the farm
so i ran into this power job and i went back to it but only worked in the fall
and on the power corporation yeah and then in the next spring mother wanted to come back on
the farm and i went back to the power company wages were 55 cents an hour they had dropped in
yeah that's when the roof
really fell in i got 82 the fall before and 55 when i come back to spring and i
independent me no way am i going to work for 55 cents an hour and i packed up
and went back to the farm and did you stay there well i i stopped in town on the way home and i
bought a rifle which i still have today and i went out shooting golfers and oh on the farm
you could always earn your keep you know we always had livestock so you always held
and we had a good home on the farm you said your your mom had moved off the farm in the meantime
just for a year she was going to retire and go into labor and she couldn't take it and who was
on the farm in the meantime uh your brother just younger myself took over the farm yes
so um you were saying that uh you had how many in your family 13 13.
oh my goodness she had 15.
yeah that's uh what my mother said when the first time she had gone to a doctor after dad died she
took a sort of a nervous breakdown and she came into my room i was thinking about that this
morning it's funny that i woke up and here was mother standing by the bed and said i think i'm
going to die this is about two months after that and so i didn't know what to do and
just my two brothers and myself were there they're both younger
so i phoned up the neighbor lady who was a widow woman and i said mother was sick whatever she
would come with me and go to the doctor in labor so we took her to apron and doctor sent her away
on a holiday that's all she needs to get away after raising 15 or 13 kids oh and i have i'm
coming back to that now the doctor said looking her over and you've had 13 children and mother said
I was afraid to tell them I'd had 15.
Two or more would make any difference.
Okay, how much schooling did you get?
Part.
What grade did you go to in school?
Oh, well, I went through grade six and about six weeks of grade seven.
Then why did you stop?
Well, the teacher we had at the time, this was country school,
and I couldn't see eye to eye.
I was at the ornery age, I guess, eh?
Well, age after age.
Well, no, I was older than that because I look back now and I say
I was in grade five when I was at the convent, and I had turned 11 that fall.
And I don't know where the years went because it seemed to me I was about 15
when I got there.
Well, I think maybe kids didn't go as well.
Mine may have taken five twice, I don't know.
Okay, so now you were saying working for the Power Corporation in 1930,
and you had a room and board, did you?
You rented a room?
At that time you could go to a private home almost anywhere and get room and board.
I paid my own room and board.
What would you have to pay for a room and board?
Oh, it's so reasonable you wouldn't believe it.
About maybe a dollar a day or so.
Maybe a dollar a day or $35 a month.
And that included your board and the whole business?
Yeah, and even throwing the laundry some places.
I wouldn't agree. How did they make any money?
Well, you'll find in that folder you have there where they're selling six loaves of bread for 54 cents.
Oh, that's true.
That tells you part of the story.
Okay, now even on your own farm then, did they own the farm by that time?
They didn't have a mortgage on it?
You know, people ask me that today.
In fact, the man that's living on the farm today has 13 children, which is sort of a coincidence.
He was at our home here about five years ago talking about the farm.
He said, how did your dad do it?
You know, he's into it right up to here.
Keeps buying more land and getting them dead people.
I said, I don't know.
I knew nothing about the financing, how Dad arranged that.
I said, Dad went in there and paid.
A big price for that prairie.
Put buildings on it.
Put fences around it.
Put a well on it that never went dry.
It cost thousands of dollars to get a well.
And I said, he died 17 years later and it was all paid for.
He didn't know.
How big a farm was it?
Just a section.
One section of the land.
So nobody was bothered then about losing the farm or mortgaging it?
Oh, yes, yeah.
We were one of the lucky ones.
Because, again, that great pool of manpower there.
You know, you had lots of manpower to do everything.
Right, because everybody had a job.
And all it cost us, we grew our own garden, our own meat and vegetables and everything.
And I remember this was during the Depression when I wasn't working.
And we'll come to that later.
When Mother would keep the four of us for ten days.
The four of us for ten dollars a month.
And we ate like every meal was a feast.
Okay, now you said, okay, you were in 1930 and you were working for the Power Corporation.
Stopped.
Went back to the farm for a little while.
And then went back and found out the wages were 55 cents.
No.
Then I went back to the, I left, I went on strike.
A one-man strike.
I didn't have a union behind me.
I went on strike.
And I went out to the farm.
And the company come back after me.
I met the general manager on the train one day.
And he said, I thought you were working.
I said, no.
I said, they only offered me 45 or 55 cents an hour.
And I'm not going to work for 55 cents an hour.
I was worth 82 cents an hour.
It was independent of me.
I was worth 82 cents an hour last fall.
And I'm worth that much now.
When they got back down a week later, I got a phone call, come to work.
So I went to work.
And my first check came through at 75 cents an hour.
And I went to the foreman on the crew.
I said, look, how come I'm only getting 75 cents an hour?
He said, when I saw your work, he says, I told them to give you the same wages you had last year.
But he said, somebody else cut it back to 75 cents.
Well, I said, right now, I'm doing 75 cents worth of work an hour and no more.
That's all.
And I was looking for the superintendent when he comes through.
And he didn't come.
He hit town on a Saturday night.
And he was looking for me.
And when I found him, I was going to really have it out with him.
The first thing he said to me, look, he said, you think you can run the crew?
I said, do you think I can?
He said, yes, I do.
Well, he said, Bill Wilson broke his leg.
And I want you to take the crew Monday morning.
He said, you wage up to 85 cents an hour.
So you didn't have to fight with him?
That was the end of the fight.
And I worked that whole summer running the crew.
And that winter, they put me taking over.
They put me taking over service work in Estevan.
And then I saw the Power Commission advertising for people.
So I went to my boss and I said, look, I said, what about that?
They want servicemen.
Well, he said, I'll tell you, they'll be around here when we're gone.
Now, I knew nothing about the government going to take over all the power companies.
But he knew that was coming.
So he said, why don't you put in your application?
I said, the job's OK if you don't go.
So I put in my application.
I had a phone call in a couple of days to come up to Regina.
And then I started working for the government.
You worked here in Regina?
They had head office here.
And you worked at it here?
No, they sent me to Saskatoon.
How long did you stay there?
Well, I'm going to say to you like I said to my fourth cousin, Lisa.
Lisa, she was only 16 years old.
And she started quizzing me one night, like you're quizzing me now,
except that she is quizzing me about my private life,
why I didn't get married until I was 38 years old and all that.
And I said, look, you know more about me than most people know.
I said, you've asked me these kind of questions,
and you're getting around to that now.
However, it's still a secret.
How long did I stay in Saskatoon?
Yes, when I was hired in Saskatoon, they had another fellow that was a practical man
but had university education.
I was a practical man with a grade seven education,
or six and a half, whatever you want to call it.
So I got the Class B district, which was Saskatoon.
Class A district was Rosetown.
When I went into Saskatoon, I was working directly under the superintendent.
And this would be what year with Dixie?
That was in 31.
I went up there in January of 31.
And after I was there, I had an easy job.
An awful easy job.
They didn't want me to be traveling
because they paid me 10 cents a mile for my car,
and that cost money.
And they felt the pinch too easy.
So I had three areas to look after going out of Saskatoon.
North, north and east, and south and east.
And 11 towns I had to look after.
So I could handle that. There was no problem.
You said you had a car.
Did you buy it when you started working?
Yes, I had a car.
Now, to come back to that, I had a windfall.
My mother was making money on the farm.
That was the years that I was in the States.
And she had $2,000 accumulated, and she gave each of us kids $500.
And you bought a car with yours?
So I bought a car, not a new car.
I bought a second-hand car for, I think, $650.
It was in good shape, almost like new.
So in other words, you didn't find that
the Depression really changed things that much.
But it wasn't affecting me, no.
Really, I didn't...
Well, you're always short on money,
but you didn't spend a dollar unless you had to.
But you had a job then all the way through the Depression?
No. Then I come to that now.
I left Sask...
In four months in Saskatoon, the superintendent asked me
if I wanted to go out to Rosetown.
And I said, why Rosetown?
Well, he said, Jimmy Jackson's got things so messed up out there,
he says we've got to let him go.
So I was transferred to Rosetown.
I said, I want the Class A wages, so...
I was getting $155 a month at the power,
and the Class A was $165 a month.
So I went to Rosetown and took over there
and enjoyed the work.
I was young and ambitious.
The power lines had been built in the wintertime
and the poles were leaning all over the place.
And so I'd go out and straighten all this up on my own.
I used to hire a young fellow in every town,
pay him 30 cents an hour,
and the two, we were a two-man crew.
I sent a bill in for the wages,
and oh, the guy in Regina, he just raised a dick,
and what authority did I have to hire a man?
So when he came out one day through the district
and he saw what I was doing,
he didn't say, boy, that looks really good.
He just made all his other district men do what I had been doing.
So that burned me up a bit.
At another time, I found some trouble on a bridge at a river
which was just outside of my territory,
and I reported that, and I got a nasty letter
telling me to stay in my own territory.
Then they sent somebody out to fix the trouble that I had found.
But you were to mind your own business.
Well, I was independent as hell.
So I told the superintendent in Saskatoon,
I said, you tell that...
guy in Regina that he better pull on his horns
or I'll tell him to stick his job.
That's what I'll tell him.
Who's in Regina?
Pardon?
Chickling.
Oh.
Had...
So...
Saving money, you know, I had money in the bank.
Oh, I bought a brand new car.
Then I traded my old one, then bought a brand new car.
It sounds like you were having a good time in the Depression.
Oh, you should have been there.
You should have been there.
And...
So about the end of September, I heard from my mother.
She said she'd like to take a trip back to Iowa.
I said, oh, nothing to it.
I phoned in during.
I said, I want leave of absence.
I said, I'm going to take my mother down on a trip to Iowa.
And, well, he said, I won't guarantee you a job.
Oh, I said, I'm not worried about a job, you know.
Independent as they come, I'm not worried about a job.
So I took my mother to Iowa.
We were gone about six weeks.
I had a rip snorting time.
I had been down there before and knew all my cousins.
And all the contacts.
Oh, yeah, we had a lot of fun.
And then when I come back, I get in the town of Midale,
where my brother married a girl from Midale.
And there they want to put a little power system in Midale.
So instead of going back to the...
A private one?
Yes.
A private one?
The village itself.
So instead of going back to the Power Commission and looking for a job,
I took on the contract of putting this thing in for them, which I did.
And then I stayed in all winter in wired homes and kept busy that way.
And the next spring, now we're into 32,
and I come back up to Regina.
Oh, hiring.
Power Commission said, we're still laying off men.
We're not hiring.
No way.
So I went back home on the farm and just coasted.
I had money in the bank.
Independent, you know.
Good home to stay in.
And I could always work enough to earn my keep.
And make a few dollars on the side here and there.
Until when?
All of 32 and into 33.
Then the power company in Estevan phoned me up one day
and asked me to come down for about a month.
So I went down and I worked in Estevan for about a month.
And then they had another project starting up there,
building another town out by Gull Lake.
And the boss said, I'm going to send you out there
to put in that distribution system.
So essentially after that you had a job, all the rest of the department?
Then, yeah.
Then I went out there and I had a job.
Well, we're still in depression.
Things are really tough, you know, but not for me.
I'm always...
Were you the only person you knew like that?
I mean, a lot of people say that there was a depression, but I can't...
Well...
It was more for married people then, right?
I'll put it this way, I guess.
I had the ability to do the work for about one and a half men all the time.
And that's the way I worked.
So that if there was work around...
You got it.
I was the guy that could...
They didn't give any preferential treatment then to people who were married?
Pardon?
They didn't give any...
They didn't give the married man more of a chance...
Well, I could have bumped a married man in Estevan,
but I said, no way.
I said, he's got two kids to keep and I can look after myself.
And you didn't have to contribute to the farm
or to your mother's upkeep or anything like that?
Oh, no.
No, I struck down, no.
But when I worked then, I worked the summer of 30.
That was the fall of 33.
Yeah, then...
In 34, then the same company said they'd put me into Gull Lake rewiring buildings,
business places that were hay-wired in, you know,
went and straightened up all the metering and everything.
And I did that, and then I worked all summer by myself.
I was a lineman by myself in towns where there was a plant,
a diesel plant operating, and they could always give me a man,
maybe a half a day at a time, and then I'd work by myself.
Saved my money.
On the 12th of October, they said, shut her down.
I was in East End.
They said, shut her down.
We've got no more money.
Well, again, those days you looked after yourself,
and I had money in the bank, and I went and I wintered myself in a hotel
where you could get a room for about $25 a month at that time,
eat in a cafe for $1 a month.
So you spent accordingly.
You spent 50 cents a day for pocket money and spent $1.
The next day you didn't spend any.
That's the way you worked.
Do you remember there being, you know,
who did the people blame for the depression?
Did people have any idea?
Did they say it was the government's fault?
Well, it's funny.
With myself, you know, there really was no depression
as far as I was concerned.
To get back to your other interviews,
I never, I was never out of a dollar, never broke, you know.
I always had money in the bank.
Save it as you go.
The first that I noticed of the depression was
in the fall of 30, we were working in Bigger,
and every train that came through there that was on the main line,
if there's a hundred cars, box cars,
there'd be men on every one of them.
Yeah, this is what the lady said.
And they had little sort of hobo jungles or something in each town.
Oh, yeah.
And these fellows would come out and go through the towns
and go to the door and ask for sandwiches.
It was out of necessity.
If you get hungry, you'll do almost anything.
That was the first that I noticed.
But it still didn't bother me.
I had a job, you know.
It amazes me that they were putting electricity into the places
when this was going on.
I know.
I was rebuilding.
No, but you said you wired a lot of homes and this sort of thing.
People were putting electricity into their house.
Well, I was in Midale.
I wired homes all winter in Midale in 19...
Who was paying for the wiring?
The people themselves.
But you wire a house, they'd put in an entrance,
which cost $18 in those days.
Now, to get that plug put in now costs you $25.
But I'd put in the main entrance coming into a house for $18,
and for $3, I'd put in an outlet or a light.
So they'd put in the very minimum.
You know, if they had five rooms, they'd put in five lights.
That was $15.
An 18, that's only $33.
Yeah.
And did most people have it put in?
Pretty well.
I'd say 75 or 80 percent of the people, yes.
Hmm.
Doesn't sound like there's that out there.
Now, this is...
Well, there were some of the ones living in the small shacks,
you know, and whatnot that didn't happen.
Did you know anybody that had to go on relief?
Oh, yes.
There were...
Well, this is...
Later on, this carried on into...
When I got back into Estevan again in 1937,
all kinds of people were living off relief,
right up until the war.
Did people treat them any differently than...
You know, did they look down on them because they were taking relief?
Not necessarily.
It was a thing you accepted.
That's the way it was.
And people living in...
You know, a crowd into like a...
You didn't live in a house like this.
Two people, you rented out every room to somebody
if you only got $10 a month for it.
But to interject there for a minute,
you said that people looked down on you if you were on relief.
No, because the lawyers...
The only ones that weren't on relief were the bankers and the doctors.
The lawyers had the heels on their shoes.
The only thing is...
The same as everybody else.
My father objected to...
He had to go down the city to get his relief,
but they delivered it to the lawyers' house.
Oh, is that right?
I mean, there was...
Yeah, a difference.
A difference.
But everybody rented.
Like, again, I have to talk about Estevan and Bienfait,
the coal mines where I knew every home.
I had 1,200 customers.
I knew them all, and they all knew me
in the years that I was there.
And people were poor.
You were in sympathy with them.
I'd have to go and collect the light bills when they didn't pay,
and I...
The most heartbreaking thing,
you'd go to a door and pound on the door,
and here's a woman come to the door.
She had three, four little kids trailing her there.
And you were supposed to collect money
because she was $5 behind on her light bill.
The government paid them $1.50.
On relief?
For lights.
That was it.
And anything over that, they had to pay.
And that was one of the heartbreaking things,
when you had to go out on collections.
And then, sure, we'd get the list,
and here was the...
some big shot in town with $70 or $80,
and he wasn't on the list to go and collect from him.
Was everything a little different?
Human nature being what it is.
But the relief came from the federal government, did it?
Federal, yeah.
Through the municipality?
Yeah, to get back to how did it affect you,
the one winter, the winter of 32,
I had nothing to do,
and my brother was home on the farm.
He said, well, I'll pay you this relief wage,
which is $5 a month,
is what the government used to pay,
$5 a month for a man on the farm.
And he paid me $8 a month.
He gave me a bonus.
But I worked 12 hours a day.
We had a lot of livestock on the place.
I was busy.
Did you grow grain as well on the farm?
Oh, yeah, grain and livestock.
And did you always have good crops?
No, a lot of failures through the years.
So you had the drought down there as well?
Well, that came after.
The drought only came really after in the 30s
when things started getting bad in that respect.
But by that time I was away from farming.
It didn't affect you then?
No.
Do you remember what the price of wheat might be?
Yeah, I had some.
When that one year I farmed,
I had a few hundred bushels,
and I guess I could have sold it that fall
for maybe a dollar or something a bushel.
And I thought, I'll hold it.
It'll go up.
And I wound up selling it for about 60 cents a bushel.
Wheat went as low as 30 cents a bushel.
But that area obviously didn't get completely dried out
because you said you had gardens, farm gardens.
Yeah, that's right.
You could always grow a garden.
But I don't know how the pastures were dried out.
And you had to sell off your livestock.
The government wouldn't give you money
if you couldn't grow hay.
The government wouldn't buy your hay,
excepting for two cattle, two cows, that's all.
Things were tough in that respect.
And still in our local area there was not bad.
I was out west between Shaunavon and Cinnaboya
in 35 and 36,
and there it was terrible.
And I might add,
when I was at Rosetown in 1937,
that's on the main road north from Swift Current,
that people were migrating up there.
It was an endless stream.
Migrating out of that area?
Out of the dry country,
down south of Swift Current, going north.
You could go out on the highway
and get up on a high area somewhere,
and as far as the eye could see,
there'd be one of these hay racks with a cow behind it,
maybe a Bennett buggy like you see pictures of there.
And about every half mile there'd be one of these,
and a whole family up there.
And a half mile there'd be one of these,
and a whole family up there,
taking a trek up.
They went up into the Meadow Lake.
And a lot of them never came back, did they?
Oh, they did well up there.
In 1957 we built power lines up there,
and these were the people that had migrated up there into the woods,
had it all cleared out and had beautiful farms.
Now, going back to the...
Who did people blame?
The government or the Depression?
Government.
But it wasn't...
See, Saskatchewan was not only hit with the Depression,
we were hit with the growth, which made it doubly bad.
Right.
Were people politically involved, do you think?
Well, where else do you go?
You blame the government, you know.
Where are you going to go for help?
You start with the municipal level
and then the provincial level,
and it finally winds up in Ottawa.
No, no, but I meant, did people...
Did they have political opinions?
The other lady I talked to said that people weren't politically aware.
Not like they are today.
They tended to be small town and...
Because we didn't have this.
We didn't...
Well, yeah, we had radios,
but I'd say only half of the families had radios.
I didn't say they blamed the government, Linda.
Well, that's what...
Because it was so gross.
I mean, you can't blame the government
because you can't grow anything.
Yeah, but all this bunch...
You'll see pictures of train loads
when they come through Ejani
or going down to Ottawa to raise hell,
blame the government because they weren't...
Well, they didn't blame them for the drought,
but they weren't getting anything...
But for the Depression, they were.
Yeah.
For the crisis and stuff like that.
It was really...
People were not as informed
at that time as they are now.
And I say, God help us
if it ever gets as bad now as it was then.
I'm afraid for what will happen.
Did they have any idea of how long...
Did people think it would last very long?
You never look ahead that far.
And I suppose because everybody was pretty well
in the same predicament.
Everybody's in the same boat.
Yeah, farmers...
You know, people were hard up.
I'll tell you where I noticed it most
during the years.
Like, I went to Iowa in 1931,
and then I took my mother down again in 1938.
And when you got down there,
there was no Depression.
Well...
Financial matters,
but people had everything.
When you went to church on Sunday,
everybody was dressed so nice down there.
And here, when you went to church on Sunday,
people were really dressed shabby, you know.
Old coats and old clothes and everything.
It showed up.
But it never really did affect you
as far as clothing and that kind of thing did?
No.
One fellow told me, he said,
I always remember you as a young man.
He was about my age.
And then he went out banking.
He said, the only thing I could ever remember about you,
you were always kind of a sporty dresser.
Well, I didn't think I was.
You had just yourself to keep.
I thought I didn't have a winter overcoat for three years.
You were married in 1938, did you say?
So you were married then after the Depression.
Yeah, that was one of the things that I saw.
These fellows getting married during the Depression,
they didn't have anything in their homes.
They'd get in an old house someplace
and have apple boxes with curtains on and so forth.
It was brought up in a good home.
And I said, I'd never want to marry a girl
and take her into a deal like that.
And I didn't have the wherewith to start a home.
So you intentionally didn't marry then?
Intentionally didn't get married until I...
Good job the Depression didn't go on a long, long time.
A couple more years.
I had one brother who never did marry.
He's a schoolteacher.
For the same reason, I suppose.
Yeah, he was a schoolteacher.
He never had enough money to get married.
Well, this other lady I was interviewing said that
a lot of people were engaged for a long, long time,
just because they couldn't afford to get married.
I had a brother who was engaged for eight years.
Is that right?
Just couldn't afford to get married.
Yeah, that's right.
The other thing I wanted to know was about
what they did with their spare time,
what you did socially.
Well, it's funny, even before you've fallen here,
when you get older, you think about things that come back to me.
When I was home on the farm,
again, in the wintertime you're tied up,
about four of us neighbor young gang would get together
and would, one house after the other, would,
this was stag, put on a party, stag party.
A couple of them were bachelors,
the people were away on holidays,
and we'd go there and play poker.
Used matches, a penny a match.
You didn't have that many pennies.
Sure, the Orsett boys.
The Orsett, homemade beer?
No, we didn't drink at that time.
That was before beer came into being,
before liquor came.
Those parties were dry.
Ice cream party, make cake and ice cream and all.
That's what we young fellas used to do.
And nobody made any, what do you call it?
Homebrew?
Yeah, homebrew.
No, not then.
Well, my dad always made wine.
My dad always made a barrel of wine every year.
And beer?
Well, then I started making beer,
but that was in the 30s,
when we started making beer.
Yeah, in the years,
when I was home on the farm,
we made our own beer.
Two cents a bottle for a cost,
made beer just as good as you buy today.
Is that right?
Yeah.
So, and what did other people do for entertainment?
You know, there must have been a lot of men who ran.
Now, you're talking about the Depression years,
not before.
Yeah, I just want the Depression.
Yeah, because, yeah, the Depression years,
you had schoolhouse dances.
As you know, every six miles through the country,
there's a schoolhouse or something like that.
And a schoolhouse dance,
and it would cost you 35 cents.
And somebody put it on
and paid the guy with the violin or the organ,
whatever it was,
and you had a lunch and everything for 35 cents.
That's more darn less than you could shake a stick at.
And I suppose everybody went.
Well, all the young people,
oh, sure, they were always plugged.
No matter how cold it was or how much snow it was,
you'd get there in the wintertime and have a great time.
Schoolhouse.
And then the small towns have a dance.
Maybe once a month you'd have a dance in your small town.
That was your entertainment.
And you had radio?
Yeah, we got a radio about 1923, I think,
the first out.
I remember one dad,
his dad came home one day with a radio
with just headsets,
and we used to put it in a bowl,
and then we could all hear it.
In a bowl?
Yeah.
Open an amplifier, I suppose.
A big bowl, like,
what do you have in those big bowls?
A crystal bowl.
Oh, yeah.
Making bread.
Big ceramic bowl,
and you put it in there,
and it echoed out.
That sounds like sitting under the towel
to watch the TV.
Yeah.
I remember when they first came out,
the TVs were so snowy,
and you couldn't see them.
You had to sit with a towel over.
No, I never experienced that.
Oh, geez, I remember that.
Well, we were in the city here,
we always had pretty good reception.
But that, yeah, radios come out,
and you'd listen to David McKee and Molly.
You read, you did a lot of reading.
I've seen at home,
when I was home on the farm that winter,
everything was read in the house.
Two or three times, of course.
You didn't have a library like this, you know.
You'd get a book from the neighbor,
and you'd read it.
Pass it along.
Yeah.
Did the men who were unemployed,
did they have a problem with their spare time?
They went out, and there were,
at that time, we probably had
80 or 90,000 farms in Saskatchewan.
And the farmer was paid $5 a month
to keep this fellow out there.
So the farmer, if he had a room,
he'd get one of these men out there.
And did they pay him?
And that fellow, he was lucky.
If he got the $5,
you know.
But he got room and board.
The farmer got paid.
He got room and board,
and he kept busy, you know,
something like that.
And everybody else was doing the same thing,
you know.
So it wasn't that bad.
Do you know anything about
what they did for medical care?
Was there any medical aid or
things for these people?
I never knew of anyone dying,
excepting one woman,
a neighbor woman,
I had about,
probably her 10th or 12th baby,
and she died from childbirth,
just a neighbor a couple miles away.
Other than that,
I never knew of anybody dying
from want of medicine.
Did they have a doctor
and a nurse, right?
We had a doctor at Griffin,
which was 10 miles away,
but that wasn't our town.
Mydale doctor was the one
that would come out.
But for a doctor to come to the farm
in the wintertime
was almost unheard of.
So you did most of the doctoring
yourself?
Oh, yeah.
I remember sticking a fork
into my foot one time.
A few hours I had blood poison.
But you had some home remedy
and it cured it.
So one of the more people
didn't die, didn't you?
I remember that one was
hot coals in a pail
and throw some wool rags
and put a blanket over
and put your foot in.
I don't know whether it was
the heat or the smoke
that cured it,
but it cured it anyway.
Is that right?
I remember doing that.
I stuck a nail in my foot
and I can remember.
They had to soak it,
so it was both the same thing.
Well, in fact,
you didn't.
Yeah, well,
it would be contaminated.
I remember this was
in the summertime, too.
I had an attack
to appendicitis.
That was that summer
when I was home on the farm
about 33.
I was out pitching bundles
folded over.
I had such a pain in here.
Later on,
for a couple of days,
one whole day,
I laid in bed
putting a cold ice cream
and putting cold irons
on there too.
That was supposed
to be good for it.
Oh, it went away.
I've never had an operation
of this game.
I never heard of anyone
dying for want of medicine.
Did you have soup kitchens
and that kind of thing
in your town?
No.
It was too small?
No.
See, small communities
had a big advantage.
Everybody sort of looked
after everybody.
What, shared?
Food and that sort of thing.
Well, I don't know.
If you saw somebody
that needed help,
you helped them.
That was...
So you don't think
the government did much,
really, then,
to alleviate
any of the problems?
They didn't...
Well, the municipalities
handled it.
You could get help,
financial help
from the municipality.
What did they send in?
Salt, fish and apples?
Oh, yeah.
The government sent...
From the east?
From the east.
Did everybody get that?
Oh, yeah.
You went down
to see Holland.
Oh, yeah.
You went down
to see Holland.
And the mother said,
I don't want any...
And the storekeeper said,
you get in there
and get your box of apples.
You're entitled to it.
It's for everybody.
Is that right?
The mother,
very reluctantly,
took a box of apples.
But...
Huh?
If you were
self-sufficient,
you really didn't...
You lived on a farm.
You could basically survive.
You had a cow.
You maybe didn't
have much money,
but you could...
You could sell
your apes,
you could sell
your odd chicken,
you had your vegetables,
you had your meat.
So you got
a little sugar
and a little salt.
But if you lived
in town,
you were on
the relief period.
Yeah.
Right.
But...
It goes back,
again,
the guy took
a hundred pounds
of flour home
and a half of pork
for a couple of bucks
and they got
through the winter
somehow.
But they didn't
allow...
I mean,
anybody who owned
a store didn't
allow much credit,
did they?
Oh, yeah.
They did.
They did up
to a point
where they didn't
sell it off.
Yeah.
Small towns,
small communities,
it was the same
with neighbors.
We had neighbors,
well, this was
even before
the Depression,
that didn't
have feed
or anything
for their animals
and we were...
The guy wanted
to know if he could
get a load of straw.
Well, he came up there
with a team of horses
that could hardly
pull the empty sleigh
and they were
so hard up
for feed.
So dad said
to us,
boys,
and he said
to another one,
he said,
hitch a team
of horses on
and pull him
home.
He was two miles
away.
Dad, you help
people like that
and throw,
maybe throw some oats
in the two
that he could
feed his horses.
Looking awfully
desperate for people
though.
You had big
families and
no jobs.
Yeah.
And that's been
just terrible.
Of course,
there again,
as I said,
our home
was a little
different.
So there was
a sense of community
and a sense of
closeness more
than there is now.
Oh, very definitely.
It was so different
that I can remember
this neighbor lady
that I got
when mother was sick
and this after
dad was dead.
They were going
to sell out
and go back
to Illinois
and her son
took sick.
She just had
the one son
who was about
my age.
So she asked
if I'd come up
and get them
ready for an
appointment.
And I went up
there and I
worked like a slave
besides doing
the chores at home
and I'd go up
and work there
and I got all
our horses
trimmed up
and dressed up
for the sale
and everything
arranged,
got neighbors
in and we dug
out the machinery
and all the
while she kept
saying,
oh Linda and I
don't know
what I'd do
without you.
I will pay
you a bill.
She'd always
say I will
pay you a bill.
It didn't hurt
me.
No.
Another neighbor
almost in the
same direction,
he was a bachelor
and he got me
to come and take
his horses in
off of the prairie
and trim them
up and everything
and he always
used that term,
he's a Scandinavian,
I'll pay you a
bill,
I'll pay you
a,
give me a
mahogany table
about that big,
that was the
pay I got
for it.
So do you think
you think people
did a lot
of trading
and that was
sort of like
barter rather than
paying cash
for things,
they'd bring
butter or whatever?
No, I never saw
any of that go on
in the small towns
really.
Well the barber
in my day,
he's still living,
he's over a hundred
years old,
he would do
that,
he would trim
hair for butter
or cream
or potatoes
or eggs
what have you
and he
goes down
but you're
out on the
road and you
had to pull in
and you were
afraid to be
out on the
road,
you couldn't
see the
length of a
car in front
of you.
And that would
go on for days
I suppose,
would it?
Day and night
sometimes,
yeah.
Did that affect
people?
No, you got
accustomed to
being dirty
all the time,
you know.
Yeah.
I can remember
working in
Chandovan
and we
went to
Chandovan to
a Cinnaboy
and we would
go out every
morning,
a nice bright
morning,
and by the
time the
sun got up
good and it
got hot,
the wind would
start up and
by 11 o'clock
in the morning
you had a
hit for cover.
It just seemed
to create a
draft,
you know,
it'd come
all the way
from Lethbridge
down,
the whole
country was
starving to
death,
it was that
bad.
Birds starved
to death.
Yeah,
just nothing
grew I guess.
Nothing grew
except in Russian
thistles and
they'd get about
so high.
But it did
rain sometimes.
Well,
and it started
raining and
they grew 20
crops in a row
after that.
Well,
of course all it
did was just
They had missed
just about 20
crops too,
you know,
what was the
weather like
in that
area,
like people
who had
immigrated
into,
you know,
people from

different places,
did people feel
that there was
enough to go
around or not
enough and
they weren't
willing to
care?
Well,
see,
I don't
know what
you refer
to when
you say
prejudices,
people coming
and the first that we saw of anyone that had any what we call foreign blood in them is a bunch of
they would be from german extraction i guess came in from maple creek they had gone out in that

in wagons they come into our district and if there's a vacant farm they got on it
and people you know you come there one year there's one and three years there's a half a dozen
more so they finally come in and now basically that's what's in the community did people resent
them coming in no no they treated them just the same as it was one of the things you accepted
you felt sorry for the guy you know it sounds to me like there was a real sense of neighborliness
then you know a case of survival
that's how you did it do you do you remember the church being very involved in any of their

well i can speak for esteban too i never saw anything uh organized there really or a weyburn
we're in a small community in halbright we're the only church between
two places but there's never anything uh done for the poor or anything not like we're doing today
in any of the churches there of course i suppose the churches is you know the people in the church
didn't have any money either so i suppose that would be well the church is the people put it

so after the war started when the war started yeah then you could see things starting to pick up a

that was a just like that into the army because it was a guaranteed wage then the relief was cut

they they they you said they cut the relief off as soon as the war started
well not immediately but it soon followed in other words does it mean getting the army as
fast as they could mobilize do you remember them having conscription oh yeah well i was
for conscription what did people feel about that that's the way it should be is that right
there weren't people they didn't oppose to the idea of conscription at all no i never heard anyone
because it was so different than that in the east a lot of people were really really opposed
to this well of course well we hadn't had a war just before that the world war was only
20 years old when this one had ended only 20 years when this one excellent started you know
a lot of patriotism down here more so than there is today i think yeah well although we don't know
if a war started now you'd probably see yeah but i think they had more links to britain people felt
more because because britain was at war that canada should go at war too because it was you
know that tie well i don't know what they would know you know canada's much more independent well
a lot a lot of them probably
we haven't got unemployment yet it's not bad yet you know you talk about unemployment i'll get back
to that when i was in saskatoon in the spring of 31. i saw lines of traveling men travelers taken

town and take orders for things and sell things like traveling sales from the whole wholesale house
yeah i've seen lineups
two abreast three shitty blocks long waiting to get lined up down to the employment office
or else the relief where they got relief that was the first guy that suffered was a fella
that was not out uh producing anything you know he went first now i wouldn't be surprised to see

what we've got now not what i've seen it's uh conditions are so bad for it now when i went

about 300 maybe 275 300 people living there and i went in there by myself
and now i have to get a crew of eight ten men i could have picked up 30
just like that and that's not on good young men i had to almost fight them off to keep them from

and took over all these corporations as a means of employment for the no it was a
of a natural evolution uh it's funny you should ask that question i just finished reading a book

form but i wasn't involved like he explained all the things that went on between the private

in alberta has happened here sort of a natural evolution invention uh economic conditions and

tommy douglas always said you know we give all the farmers power
well we'd have got power no matter if there's a liberal or conservative what government was in

who was in power over the over the depression oh the anderson government came in that was a

uh they lasted four years they came in when things were just starting to get bad
and then they just got worse and when they went out they never got a seat
four years now that tells you that people are blaming the government
you remember hearing about uh bennett just before the election he promised a whole lot of things
like employment insurance and all these kind of things that well as i say we were not as informed
and i can remember that he was supposed to when he came in he was going to turn the whole world

know it was the same thing saw stall they couldn't find answers until the war came i always say
give hitler credit he he put a stop to the depression in north america
starting that war and that made work and from there back we built up and now we've hit another
dead end we'll probably have another war we could see it you could see this dead end coming i could
see it for the last five years i've said there's too much of everything we've out manufactured

it's all right well they say well people should buy more cars
yeah you can only use so many cars
but i could see it in my own uneducated way in regina here the used car a lot

the towns in between all plugged full of used good used cars not junk cars good used cars so they
reach the
saturation points go through the stores the stores are plugged so full of merchandise and they're

Well, everybody else is doing it.

Well, yeah.
You were living very well.
Well, I didn't live extravagantly, though.
I say now, though, in those years when I was a migrant lineman, I had a little bit of a
habit.
I had a suitcase, a club bag, and I could put the rest of the stuff in a carton that
I owned.
You kept yourself down to the basics.
You always had a good suit and an extra pair of pants.
You didn't have two jackets.
No.
And when you wore the pants, you wore a sweater with them.
That's easy to pack, you know.
Right.
Right.
So nobody had any frills.
And a good pair of dress shoes, and that was, that's all.
Yeah.
Nobody had any frills or anything.
They just had the bare necessities.
That's right.
Yeah.
And that's the way you lived.
Yeah.

Everything.

Save.

I saved.

Yeah, that's right.

In other words, you never knew when it was going to stop.
Paul was a very hard worker.
I was always a hard worker.

There were nine girls and four boys in that family. They lived just a mile away. Now what

No, they came up five years after us. And so they migrated to California. All of them? Well,
first the oldest girl, and the mother, and the father, and a pair of twins about 15 years old,

But it's funny, they all scattered. It didn't turn out the way dad had it planned at all.
The other thing I was just thinking about, you said that you never had,
single men never had a problem getting a job as opposed to married men.
No, because the company looked at it. Here's a guy, you know, that he can be a migrant. We
don't want him. Well, we can get rid of him. If he's married, you have a responsibility.
I know this other lady was saying that she was a school teacher.
And when she married, she had to quit. They wouldn't have people who were married being
school teachers. Well, I run a business for 20 years, and I was the same. I always hired single
men. Yeah, I suppose. Do you remember the big trek that came through Regina? All those young
men who were unemployed, and they had them in the labor camps, and they came here, and they had the
riot. Do you remember that? Oh, yeah, I remember that. There again, but that was an
accumulation of men right from Victoria through, you see. Yeah. They didn't, they weren't from the
district here or anything like that. What did people think about them? They didn't pay much
attention to it. The same, I drove into Estevan after they had the big strike, the coal miner
strike down there and shot two or three guys. I drove into town, and they had martial law on,
and I didn't know what was wrong. It was so quiet, about five in the afternoon. Yeah. I stopped at a
service station. The guy said, didn't you have a job? I said, no, I don't have a job. He said, no,
you don't have a job. I said, no, you don't have a job. He said, no, you don't have a job. He said, no,
I said, no. I said, what's happened, Jack? There's nobody around. He said, got martial law here. He
said, there's just a big riot here this afternoon. I hadn't heard a thing about it. I didn't pay much
attention to it either. It was one of those things that happened. So, people really weren't in
sympathy much with these people who went on strike then, were they? Excepting the miners, because
everybody else didn't pay too much attention to it. Were there very many of the unions developed?
That's, yeah, they were developing unions at that time.
Were people enthusiastic? Pardon?
Were people glad that this was happening, the unions? Did they think they were a good idea?
Well, they didn't pay much attention to it, but the miners.
Anybody who didn't have anything much, they were the ones who were more sort of ones?
Well, the miners were getting a bad deal, there's no doubt about it. But things were tough,
I mean, for the mine company to make it go to.
Were there many people who were
communists?
Well, they said the guy that came in there, this Annie Buller, she's a woman from Winnipeg,
and what was the other fellow's name? The ringleader. They said he's a communist, but
he was making a living organizing. That was the same as all these,
this McDermott we have down in Ottawa now. He's got a job to do. He's got to holler and
castigate all the big companies and everything for treating his men so bad. How does he earn a hundred
thousand a year if you don't?
So it sounds like that anybody who started making go of it, they didn't bother politically or they
weren't involved in the unions. They were just glad to be left alone. It was only the people
who were really, really hurting or on relief that sort of got involved in those kind of things,
were they?
